org.jimmutable.core.objects

Class StandardObject<T extends StandardObject<T>>

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.jimmutable.core.objects.StandardObject<T>
  • Type Parameters:
    T - The object that is extending StandardObject. This fixes the typing for serialization, cloning, etc.
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    Comparable<T>, StandardWritable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    StandardImmutableObject

    public abstract class StandardObject<T extends StandardObject<T>>
extends Object
implements Comparable<T>, StandardWritable
    The root for all "standard" objects. All data in the framework, whether abstract, final, component, or container, should - directly or indirectly - inherit from StandardObject.

    Standard objects all support:

    • XML Serialization (read & write)
    • JSON Serialization (read & write)
    • Hashing, comparison, equality testing (i.e. can be included in any of the standard Java collection implementations, including Set and Map)
    • Standardized normalization of data field values
    • Standardized validation of data field values

    Extending StandardObject is kind of like shouting out to the world "hey, I am good, little, normal boy that is well behaved".

    StandadObject(s) may be mutable. If you wish to create an immutable standard object (by far the most common type) you should extend StandardImmutableObject.

    Author:
    Jim Kane
    See Also:
    StandardImmutableObject

    • Method Detail

      • normalize

        public abstract void normalize()
        Normalize the fields of the object. The idea is to clean up the values of fields when possible (e.g. all uppercase letters, empty collection).

        It is expected that implementations of normalize will never throw an Exception. Work done during normalization should be tolerant of bad vales (e.g. null). If there's something wrong with a value, validate() will catch it.

        In StandardImmutableObject, the object is guaranteed to be mutable at the point normalize is called.

        validate() is called after normalization. The idea is that you are given a chance to fill in/correct fields before a validation check is made.

      • validate

        public abstract void validate()
        Validate the fields of the object. Standard practice is to simply call the various validation methods in Validator to do the heavy lifting.
        Throws:
        ValidationException - if something is not "up to snuff"

      • complete

        public void complete()
        Declare that an object is ready to use. The practical effect is that normalization and validation is done on all fields.

        Complete must only be called once in an object's life cycle. Typically, standard object's call complete at the end of their standard constructor.

        When building complicated class hierarchies, the decision of where to call complete can become complicated. Why? Well, complete can only be called once so you need to call it at the end of the constructor in the "leaf" classes. Declaring leaf classes final is a good "heuristic" way to get started with this in many cases. In more complicated cases, you may need to add arguments to base class constructors "am I the leaf?" to control completion.

      • deepClone

        public T deepClone()

        A deep copy of this object

      • toJavaCode

        public String toJavaCode(Format format,
                         String variable_name)
        Create Java source code that will construct an identical copy of this object.

        This is done by taking the pretty printed XML and properly escaping it (using JavaCodeUtils) so as to make clean, easy to read Java source code that will construct the object. (Effectively serializing the object to Java source code!)

        This is super useful when creating unit tests of serialization... Just saying...

        Returns:
        Java statements that will construct a copy of this object from the format specified
